title: In Baniyas, Syria, the story of a Sunni who saved Alawites from massacre: 'We acted out of simple humanity'
summary: In the district of Baniyas, executions perpetrated against Alawites by Sunni factions caused around 100 deaths. A man in his sixties hid several Alawite families in his apartment in a Sunni neighborhood in the city center.

title: US flies alleged gang members to El Salvador despite court block
summary: The deportations took place despite a US federal judge granting a temporary suspension of the expulsions order, apparently as planes were headed to El Salvador. The move raised questions over whether the Trump administration deliberately defied the court decision.

title: The threats to public health in Trump's US
summary: Massive cuts in federal agency staff, funding suspended or cancelled, data made inaccessible: the 47th president of the US has plunged the world of science into chaos, without sparing the biomedical sphere. The fightback is getting organized, notably around the 'Stand Up for Science' movement.

title: Israel: Netanyahu seeks to fire internal security agency chief
summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that he was seeking to dismiss Shin Bet head Ronen Bar. The internal security agency chief swiftly called the move political and said the premier expected 'personal loyalty'.

title: DRC's Goma, after the M23 attack: a city at a standstill and cut off from the world
summary: The economy of the North Kivu capital, seized by the rebel movement and its Rwandan allies in late January, has ground to a halt due to the airport's closure and the paralysis of the banking system.

title: Belgian actress Emilie Dequenne dead at 43
summary: Her first role in 'Rosetta', by the Dardenne brothers, launched her career after she won best actress at the Cannes Film Festival for her performance in the film, which also won the Palme d'Or.

title: Yemen Houthi rebels say they attacked US carrier after air strikes
summary: The Iran-backed group said they had launched 18 missiles and a drone at the US aircraft carrier USS Harry Truman and its accompanying warships, in response to US strikes on Saturday. There was no immediate comment from the United States about the claim.

title: Vatican releases first photo of Pope Francis in over a month
summary: In a message earlier on Sunday, the pope said he was 'facing a period of trial' and thanked well-wishers.

title: Belgrade's historic day of anger: Hundreds of thousands of Serbians protest for 'laws and justice that work'
summary: The country's authoritarian president, Aleksandar Vucic, was the protestors' main target at the large anti-corruption demonstration, following the fatal accident at the Novi Sad train station. Saturday's movement was reminiscent of those that led to the fall of former dictator Slobodan Milosevic in 2000.

title: In the US, some Democrats step back from gender and minority issues
summary: Following the example of California Governor Gavin Newsom, many Democrats are distancing themselves from the party's usual position on minority rights issues.

title: Polish far right picks up steam as presidential election approaches
summary: Slawomir Mentzen, the far-right Konfederacja alliance candidate, is polling at 22% ahead of the Polish presidential election on May 18.

title: Gad Elmaleh: 'I'm at a point in my life where I have a more selfish desire to leave a mark'
summary: Driven by a desire to pass on and discover new talent, the 53-year-old comedian and actor talks to Le Monde about why he is getting involved in new stand-up venues.

title: Architect in charge of Nice contemporary art museum's renovation dismissed
summary: The city has parted company with Portuguese architect Joao Luis Carrilho da Graça, who was chosen to redevelop the MAMAC. He is contesting the decision before an administrative court.

title: Nightclub fire in North Macedonia kills at least 59, wounds more than 150
summary: The fire broke out early Sunday in the eastern town of Kocani during a concert by a local pop group, according to the interior minister. Pyrotechnics caused the roof to catch fire, he said.

title: French MEP says US should give back Statue of Liberty
summary: Raphaël Glucksmann, a center-left member of the European Parliament, has strongly criticized President Donald Trump's radical change of US policy on the war in Ukraine.

title: Matteo Jorgenson retains title in Paris-Nice race
summary: The American rider, who lives in Nice, won the eight-day race ahead of German hope Florian Lipowitz and Dutch climber Thymen Arensman.

title: Maria Mazzotta's punk-rock tarantellas
summary: The Italian singer with a powerful voice brings her second solo album, 'Onde,' to the French stage.

title: European armies seek to urgently end dependence on US
summary: The wake-up call has been especially brutal for the Europeans, as the war in Ukraine had significantly deepened their dependence on the entire American military system – from fighter jets and satellites to artillery, munitions and telecommunications.

title: French beauty industry fears Washington's wrath
summary: In response to the trade war started by Donald Trump, the European Union is considering taxing make-up products and essential oils from the US. The European cosmetics industry therefore fears it will be targeted by the US president in retaliation.

title: Paris Saint-Germain defeat Marseille 3-1 in Ligue 1
summary: PSG followed their Champions League victory over Liverpool on Tuesday by getting the better of Marseille at the Parc des Princes on Sunday in a meeting of the top two in Ligue 1. Meanwhile, the clash between relegation battlers Montpellier and Saint-Etienne was abandoned due to crowd trouble.

title: Edith Heard, geneticist: 'I had to come to France to put down roots and blossom'
summary: 'I wouldn't have got here if...' Every week, 'Le Monde' interviews a well-known person about a decisive moment in their life. The French-British researcher, a professor at the Collège de France, looks back on the development of her relationship with science.

title: Five years after Covid, Paris region dwellers who fled toward nature aren't looking back
summary: Lockdown heightened the desire of many Paris region residents to relocate for more space and greenery. While the flow has since slowed, many of them feel they made the right choice by taking advantage of new remote work opportunities and leaving the capital and its surroundings.

title: Who really was Saint Patrick? From mystical visions to beer festivals
summary: Between history, spirituality and legend, the figure of Saint Patrick, who has become a key element of a tormented Irish identity, tells the story of the slow Christianization of an island that has never completely abandoned its ancestral traditions.

title: At Paris's Gonflé bakery, the Armorican cookie is 'enhanced by the grainy flavors of toasted buckwheat'
summary: Every week, a journalist describes a memorable product or eating experience, such as these two cookies from the window of Gonflé, the new Parisian bakery run by pastry chef Timothy Breton.

title: The French university welcoming American researchers targeted by Trump's administration
summary: Aix-Marseille University wants to fund the work of some 15 academics in fields targeted by the new US administration.

title: At Le Scouarnec's child abuse trial, the victims' sobs, anger and trauma
summary: According to the investigation, many of the hundreds of people raped and abused as children by the surgeon only learned of the facts from the police. They recounted their shock before the Brittany criminal court.

title: Kremlin confirms Putin, Trump to speak Tuesday
summary: Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov confirmed the meeting to reporters on Monday, including AFP, but hasn't issued any further comments.

title: Emilie Dequenne: Belgian actress dies after months of battling rare cancer
summary: Dequenne died on Sunday, at the age of 43. A remission last May enabled her to celebrate the 25th anniversary of 'Rosetta,' the film that made her name and won her Best Actress at Cannes, in 1999.

title: Rwanda says cutting diplomatic ties with Belgium
summary: According to Kigali, Belgium has 'consistently' undermined Rwanda when it comes to the offensive launched by Rwandan-backed M23 in DRC

title: OECD lowers its global growth projections citing 'trade barriers' and 'uncertainty'
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development adjusted its 2025 projection from 3.3% growth to 3.1%, in a reaction to mounting trade tensions and geopolitical uncertainty since US President Donald Trump took office.

title: Canadian PM Carney says his country must bolster ties with 'reliable allies'
summary: Speaking in a joint press conference with Emmanuel Macron, Mark Carney, Canada's new prime minister, cited France as a 'reliable' ally, amid a tense context marked by US President Donald Trump's tariff pressure and expansionist rhetoric toward Canada.

title: Fabien Galthié, the coronation of the misunderstood French rugby coach who understood that 'victory is the only token of performance'
summary: The French national team's coach won the 2025 edition of the Six Nations Tournament on Saturday. His second trophy at the helm of Les Bleus.

title: Drug trafficking in France: How a consensual bill became politically divisive
summary: The bill, which was passed unanimously in the Sénat, will be subject to a more tense debate in the Assemblée, starting on Monday.

title: WHO chief warns US aid cuts could cost millions of lives
summary: World Health Organization chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said that disruptions to global HIV programs alone 'could undo 20 years of progress, leading to more than 10 million additional cases of HIV and three million HIV related deaths.'

title: 'The upheavals caused by Trump's return can give the feeling of being in a dystopia come true'
summary: In France, two books published at the start of the year imagine a near-future in which far-right politician Marine Le Pen becomes president. According to their authors, such a scenario would have consequences for the rule of law, writes Le Monde journalist Solenn de Royer in her column.

title: The quoll, a threatened strangeness
summary: In February, 24 individuals of this species were released into a 6,000-hectare sanctuary in the heart of Tasmania, in the hope of halting the decline of this funny little animal.

title: French minister says U-turn on retirement age 'not realistic'
summary: The government has indicated in recent days that it would not budge on the reform's flagship measure, an increase in the retirement age from 62 to 64.

title: In Syria's coastal villages, the Alawite community feels abandoned by the new authorities: 'We want the attackers to be punished'
summary: Between March 7 and 9, the towns of al-Sanobar and Huraysun were taken over by Islamist factions allied with the new Syrian authorities. The assailants looted and burned houses and massacred dozens of inhabitants, whom they suspected of being supporters of the former regime. Survivors, still in shock and terrified, tell the story.
